body: We need to make sure that the 3d outputs does not elide trailing singleton dimensions
@lostanlen That is done. Is the rest of this issue solved?
@janden can be closed now, isn't it?
Remind me where this was fixed again?

Hi, I tried running a 3D transform with J=3, L=5, and input size (128, 128, 128) and found an output shape of (B, 10, 6, P) with method='integral', which I don't think is consistent with what's listed here https://www.kymat.io/userguide.html#id14. 

It also looks like 'standard' and 'local' aren't permitted for 3D currently--doing either of these gives me the same output shape as 'integral', but perhaps I'm using the package incorrectly.

My intuition/[empirical evidence](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1Gtzpvy9q7E2R_vuBeOWNdk0w8dkkER0F#scrollTo=qkCPtK6_p3NA) (thanks to @eugenium's tutlege in my research endeavors) tells me that with a `max_order=1`, the output shape will be `(B, C, J+1, L+1, P)` and with `max_order=2`, the output shape will be `(B, C, J+1 + J(J+1)/2, L+1, P)` 

The number depends on the number of filters generated for first order and second order wavelets. I'll submit a pull request shortly. 

Thanks for reporting @nshervt @mburhanpurkar

issue.title: DOC Output shape documentation

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
I add some words stating that the output shape is dependent on the max order. I also fix the given calculation of output shape for 3d. 

Fixes Issue #454 and #639
